questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

 

  • The clinical vignette suggests anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like latanoprost increase uveoscleral outflow and lower intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues act by stimulating prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases that increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Prostaglandin analogues should be used with caution in patients with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis.
  • Prostaglandin analogues are the least suited for use in this patient as they can worsen the anterior uveitis.
  • PG Analogues can also cause cystoids macular edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: These are generally safe in uveitis unless contraindicated for systemic reasons.

 

Option B. Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic can be used for quick reduction of IOP in acute settings but does not exacerbate uveitis.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Also safe for use in reducing IOP in uveitis, unless systemic contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.

questions.text: Identify the refractive error: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

As a result of parallel rays being focused in front of the retina in the image above, myopia is indicated as the refractive error.

 

Myopia, also referred to as "short sight," is a dioptric condition of the eye in which incident parallel rays focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina while accommodation is at rest.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presbyopia: It is an age-related condition characterized by a gradual loss of the eyes' ability to focus on nearby objects, due to the hardening of the lens inside the eye.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: Also known as farsightedness, in this condition, light rays entering the eye focus behind the retina. Individuals with hypermetropia see distant objects more clearly than close ones.

 

 

 

Option D. Astigmatism: This refractive error occurs due to an irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light to be focused at multiple points in front of, on, or behind the retina, leading to blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myopia results from the focusing of light in front of the retina, making distant objects appear blurry, a condition often corrected with concave lenses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C: Onchocerca volvulus

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D: Chlamydia A to C

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Only Myasthenia gravis, among the conditions mentioned above, would show dramatic improvement after administration of an injection (Anti-ChE medication).

 

In myasthenia gravis, there is unilateral myogenic ptosis where, after a short rest, the symptoms recover rapidly.

 

A quick test in the office can be to ask the patient to look up and hold that position, and then observe if there is fatiguability of the levator muscle such that the upper eyelids start to drift downwards while the patient is looking up. The definitive diagnosis is made through various clinical, pharmacological and serologic tests.

 

Diagnostic Tests

 

1. Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test:

 

Edrophonium chloride inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby prolonging the presence of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This results in enhanced muscle strength. This test is only useful in patients with objective, measurable findings on physical exam, like ptosis or a tropia. In ptosis, a positive test is the elevation of eyelids in 2-5 minutes post administration of Tensilon. A negative response is no improvement within 3 minutes.

 

2. Ice Test:

 

This is also a simple diagnostic test that can be done in the clinic. It is highly sensitive and specific for MG. The ice test is useful for ptosis. An ice pack is applied to the affected upper eyelid for 2-5 minutes. A positive test is the improvement of ptosis by > 2mm or more. This transient improvement in ptosis is due to the cold decreasing the acetylcholinesterase break-down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th nerve palsy: This condition primarily causes abduction deficit (inability to move the eye laterally), which would not explain the ptosis nor improve with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option C. 3rd nerve palsy: Though it can cause ptosis and eye movement abnormalities, symptoms are due to mechanical dysfunctions or nerve damage and do not improve quickly with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option D. Horner syndrome: Characterized by ptosis, miosis (pupil constriction), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating), but does not involve hypotropia or improve dramatically with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane.
  • The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.
  • Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features.
  • A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Note:

 

The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fiber Electromyography

 

The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stargardt's disease

 

Silent choroid / Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease.

 

 

The 'silent choroid' or 'dark choroid' phenomenon is caused by the obscuration of the background choroidal fluorescence due to diffuse abnormalities in the retinal epithelium (RE). The accumulation of lipofuscin within the RE is a hallmark feature of Stargardt disease / Fundus flavimaculatus (FFM), which is the most prevalent type of macular dystrophy.

 

Signs:

 

  • The macula may initially be normal, later progressing to an oval 'snail slime' or 'beaten bronze appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions are seen at the level of the RPE.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Visual fields show central loss
  • FFA - Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence. Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA). shows hypofluorescent spots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Best's disease: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin-like material within the RPE but does not typically feature a silent choroid on FFA.

 

Option C. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD): AMD is associated with drusen and neovascular changes rather than a silent choroid.

 

Option D. Cystoid macular edema: This involves swelling of the macular region of the retina due to fluid accumulation in the cystoid spaces, not linked with the silent choroid phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The silent choroid or dark choroid on FFA is a distinctive feature of Stargardt's disease, caused by lipofuscin accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium, which blocks the normal choroidal fluorescence. Recognizing this feature is crucial in diagnosing and differentiating Stargardt’s disease from other macular disorders.

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhabdomyosarcoma  

 

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical and histological findings. It is a malignant tumor derived from skeletal muscle and commonly presents in the pediatric population as a rapidly enlarging orbital mass, often causing displacement of the eye (proptosis). The biopsy findings of small, round cells positive for Desmin, a muscle-specific intermediate filament, support the diagnosis. The location and aggressive nature of the tumor, indicated by bony destruction, are characteristic of rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: This is a common malignant intraocular tumor of childhood but would not typically present with bony destruction or be positive for Desmin.

 

Option B. Cavernous Hemangioma: This is a benign vascular tumor seen in adults and is not associated with rapid progression or positive Desmin staining.

 

Option C. Orbital Cellulitis: This infection would present with signs of inflammation and fever, which are not described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later
Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later

questions.text: What is the correct order of using eye drops and eye ointment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later

 

To ensure proper absorption of medication, it is recommended to use eye drops before ointment. Eye drops have a thinner consistency and are absorbed more quickly, whereas ointments are thicker and need more time for absorption. Therefore, eye drops should be used first, followed by ointment after a gap of 15 minutes, especially when using both at the same time. Ointments are typically used at bedtime due to their prolonged absorption time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later and D. Ointment first, then eye drops immediately: Incorrect because the ointment could prevent the eye drops from being absorbed properly by creating a barrier.

 

Note - Ointments are generally used last, particularly at bedtime, to maintain medication contact with the eye surface for an extended period, aiding in treatment effectiveness, especially in conditions requiring continuous exposure to the medication.

 

Option C. Eye drops first, then ointment immediately: Incorrect as applying ointment immediately after drops could interfere with the absorption of the drops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always use eye drops before eye ointment when both forms of medication are prescribed. Allowing a gap of 15 minutes between applying drops and ointment ensures maximum effectiveness of both medications without interference in absorption.

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

 

  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.
  • Signs of Suprachoroidal hemorrhage include the following:
  •  
    • Anterior chamber shallowing
    • Loss of the red reflex
    • Increased IOP, with firming of the eye
    • Wrinkling and bulging of the posterior capsule
    • Extrusion of intraocular contents: spontaneous nuclear expression, iris prolapse, vitreous prolapse
  • Maculopathy is a common consequence of hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg.
  • Excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery is the most common cause of hypotonic maculopathy.
  • Other causes include trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment.
  • Systemic causes of hypotony, usually bilateral, include dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes with hyperglycaemia, uraemia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclodialysis of uvea: This refers to the disinsertion of the ciliary body from the scleral spur, a trauma-related occurrence that can lead to a direct decrease in IOP, potentially causing hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option C. Corneal perforation: Severe enough corneal damage, such as perforation, can lead to loss of aqueous humor and a subsequent decrease in IOP, posing a risk for hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option D. Filtration site leak: This condition is specifically associated with glaucoma surgery where a leak at the filtration site can lead to a significant reduction in IOP, making it a direct cause of hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not lead to hypotonic maculopathy because it typically causes an increase in intraocular pressure, not a decrease. Understanding the distinction between conditions that increase versus those that decrease IOP is critical in the management of eye conditions and their potential complications.

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

 

Upon the application of phenylephrine, the superficial episcleral vessels lose their color, a phenomenon known as blanching. As a result, the likely conclusion is nodular episcleritis.

 

2.5% phenylephrine proves valuable in distinguishing between episcleritis and scleritis. This distinction arises from the fact that the vessels within the episclera lie close to the surface, making them susceptible to blanching. In contrast, in cases of scleritis, these vessels do not undergo such a color change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Scleritis: Scleritis involves deeper layers of the eye and is typically more painful. Vessels in scleritis do not blanch with phenylephrine due to their depth and the severity of inflammation.

 

Option C. Tenon's Cyst: This refers to a cystic lesion involving Tenon's capsule, not typically associated with the superficial vascular changes seen in episcleritis.

 

Option D. Nodular Phlycten: This is a small, nodular inflammatory lesion usually at the corneal limbus, often related to an immune response to bacterial proteins, particularly from staphylococcal or tubercular origins, not showing the same response to phenylephrine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can typically be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance and response to phenylephrine. The ability of phenylephrine to cause blanching of the inflamed episcleral vessels is a useful diagnostic tool, helping to differentiate episcleritis from more serious conditions like scleritis, where the inflammation involves deeper tissues and the vessels do not blanch.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for her myopia. She is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on her: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonometry

 

  • The image depicts the use of an Applanation tonometry. It is based on the applanation principle described by Imbert and Fick. With regards to applanation tonometry, the law states that pressure (P) can be approximated by the force (F) necessary to flatten the cornea in a fixed area, divided by the surface (S) of the flattened area. The Imbert-Fick law is defined as P=F/S.
  • The dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal) for tonometry looks as

 

 

  • Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings obtained with this tonometer are not influenced by central corneal thickness.
  • The Pascal tonometer is the preferred tonometer for measuring IOP in post-LASIK corneas.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pachymetry: This test measures the thickness of the cornea. It is important for assessing the cornea pre-LASIK but is not depicted in the image nor directly associated with measuring IOP.

 

 

Option C. Autorefractometry: This procedure determines the refractive error and prescription for glasses or contact lenses. It does not involve contact with the eye as depicted and is unrelated to IOP measurement.

 

 

Option D. A scan: This ultrasound test measures the length of the eye and is primarily used in cataract surgery planning. It does not involve the measurement of IOP.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonometry, especially applanation tonometry, is crucial for monitoring intraocular pressure post-LASIK surgery to ensure no adverse effects on eye pressure, which could lead to symptoms like headaches and eye pain as described. This test is essential for the ongoing evaluation of patients' eye health following refractive surgery.

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil.
﻿﻿﻿The vision is normal in right eye.
﻿﻿﻿Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

 

The image suggests Marcus Gunn pupil, which is seen in optic neuritis. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

 

  • ﻿﻿The condition is named after the scientist, Robert Marcus Gunn who belongs to Scotland.

 

Presentation:

 

  • Pupil appears to dilate when light is shone on it (this is also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or RAPD).
  • The affected pupil constricts less than the unaffected pupil when light is shone on it.
  • The affected pupil may even dilate when light is removed from it (this is known as the Marcus Gunn pupil phenomenon).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Diagnosed by a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) test, also called swinging flash light test, which involves comparing the pupillary response of the affected eye to that of the unaffected eye when a light is shone on them.
  • In the swinging flashlight test, a light is alternately shone into the left and right eyes. A normal response would be equal constriction of both pupils, regardless of which eye the light is directed at. This indicates an intact direct and consensual pupillary light reflex. When the test is performed in an eye with an afferent pupillary defect, light directed in the affected eye will cause only mild constriction of both pupils (due to decreased response to light from the afferent defect), while light in the unaffected eye will cause a normal constriction of both pupils (due to an intact efferent path, and an intact consensual pupillary reflex). Thus, light shone in the affected eye will produce less pupillary constriction than light shone in the unaffected eye.

 

Management:

 

  • Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause of the afferent pupillary defect, such as optic neuritis or a retinal detachment.
  • In cases where the underlying cause cannot be treated, the patient may need to wear an eye patch to alleviate symptoms caused by the unequal pupillary responses.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is called Argyl Robertson pupil: Incorrect, as Argyl Robertson pupils are associated with neurosyphilis and react to accommodation but not to light.

 

Option B. Both eyes are abnormal: Incorrect, the image specifically shows an abnormal reaction in one eye compared to a normal reaction in the other.

 

Option C. The vision is normal in the right eye: Incorrect as it is not specifically addressed in the image or scenario provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Marcus Gunn pupil, indicative of an RAPD, is a significant sign of optic nerve dysfunction often seen in conditions like optic neuritis. Detecting this early through the swinging flashlight test can guide further diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Direct invasion included the optic nerve and the other parts in contact with the tumour mass. Thus, Direct invasion is a better choice. 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignancy that arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

There are four types of retinoblastomas:

 

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated.

 

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat's eye.

 

 

Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.

 

If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

 

  • The quiescent stage: lasting from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage: results in enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.
  • The stage of extraocular extension
  • The stage of metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve invasion: While possible, it is not the most common initial route of spread but is critical once involved, as it facilitates spread to the brain.

 

Option B. Hematogenous: Represents the method for distant metastasis rather than initial local spread.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread: Uncommon in retinoblastoma since the eye lacks significant lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

 

Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a rare congenital vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and associated capillary-venous malformations affecting the brain and eye.

 

Mechanisms of glaucoma. The two main theories regarding the mechanism of glaucoma in eyes with SWS are developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle and elevated episcleral venous pressure, each of which leads to aqueous outflow restriction leading to rise in IOP. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: This is inflammation of the uvea and not a typical manifestation of SWS.

 

Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a group of genetic disorders that affect the retina's ability to respond to light, not commonly associated with SWS.

 

Option C. Keratitis: Inflammation or infection of the cornea, not linked to SWS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome, particularly those presenting with facial port-wine stains and neurological symptoms, glaucoma is a critical ocular manifestation to consider. Regular ophthalmic evaluations are essential due to the high incidence of glaucoma in these patients, focusing on managing elevated IOP to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen’s chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The largest letter on a Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc at any standard testing distance is essential for interpreting visual acuity results correctly. This standardization is fundamental in diagnosing and measuring visual acuity across different settings and distances

questions.text: What is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. This tumor is composed of a mix of ductal and myoepithelial cells, often presenting as a painless, progressive, firm mass typically located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit.

 

Details about Pleomorphic Adenoma:

 

  • Benign Nature: Despite its benign nature, pleomorphic adenoma can cause displacement of the eye and may alter vision due to its size and location.
  • Potential for Malignant Transformation: While it is primarily benign, there is a risk for malignant transformation into a carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not adequately treated or if left untreated for a long duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Although this is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, it is not as frequently occurring as pleomorphic adenoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its aggressive nature and poorer prognosis.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: This type of tumor can involve the lacrimal gland but is generally less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This is another type of malignant tumor that can occur in the lacrimal gland, but it is also less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the lacrimal gland. Overall, benign tumours are more common, thus pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumour.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is shown in the image given below? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoidal nerve block

 

The procedure shown in the given image is an anterior ethmoidal nerve block.

 

The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the roof of the nasal cavity. It is a branch of the Nasociliary nerve which in turn is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (V1). It is sometimes used in endonasal surgery.

 

Detailing the Procedure:

 

  • Purpose: Used predominantly to numb the area for surgical procedures within the nasal cavity.
  • Method: Involves injection near the anterior ethmoidal foramen to block the nerve that transmits sensation from the nasal roof.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasolacrimal duct syringing: This procedure is used to check the patency of the nasolacrimal duct. It involves flushing the duct with saline to check for blockages, typically conducted by inserting a syringe into the puncta near the medial canthus of the eye. However, this is not related to the procedure shown in the image since it involves the eye directly and is performed with the eyes open to access the puncta.

 

Option C. Infraorbital nerve block: This block anesthetizes the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, which affects the lower eyelid, upper lip, and cheek. It is generally performed via an intraoral approach at the infraorbital foramen, located below the orbit, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Trephination of the frontal sinus: This surgical procedure involves making an incision in the floor of the frontal sinus to facilitate drainage. This procedure targets a different anatomic location and involves surgical tools, not the approach shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An anterior ethmoidal nerve block is crucial for numbing the nasal cavity area, particularly in endonasal surgeries. It is essential for procedures requiring detailed work near the roof of the nasal cavity, reflecting the significance of understanding the specific nerve anatomy for effective anesthesia.

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

COVID-19 can cause various ocular manifestations, with follicular conjunctivitis being the most common. This is due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors in the cornea and conjunctiva, making them susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

FOLLICULAR CONJUNCTIVITIS:

 

 

  • The follicles appear as gray-white, round to oval elevations which measuring between 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter
  • Smaller follicles may produce a slightly irregular and velvety appearance
  • Follicles can be seen in the inferior and superior tarsal conjunctiva, and less often, on bulbar or limbal conjunctiva 
    • Acute follicular conjunctivitis is usually associated with viral (epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, Herpes zoster keratoconjunctivitis, infectious mononucleosis, Epstein-Barr virus infection) or chlamydial infections (Inclusion conjunctivitis), while chronic disease may be caused by chronic chlamydial infection (trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum) or as a toxic or reactive inflammatory response to topical medications and molluscum contagiosum infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: There are no consistent reports linking uveitis directly as a common manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: Although mucormycosis (commonly known as black fungus) has been seen in COVID-19 patients, it is generally associated with severely immunocompromised states and not directly linked as a typical ocular manifestation of COVID-19 itself.

 

Option D. Papillary Conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis, characterized by cobblestone-like nodules, is more commonly associated with allergic reactions or chronic irritation from contact lenses rather than infectious etiologies like COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

 

  • Capsulorrhexis is a step in the conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) method.
  • It is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens.
  • Anterior capsulotomy can be done by 3 methods:
    1. Can-opener's technique
    2. Linear capsulotomy or envelope technique
    3. Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis
  • Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered superior because it does not leave any edges or tears when done correctly.
  • Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility during the procedure.
  • In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex while leaving the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact.
  • After capsulorrhexis, hydro dissection is performed using a balanced salt solution to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule.
  • Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted, and the incision is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrodissection: Hydrodissection involves injecting fluid under the anterior capsule to separate the lens nucleus from the cortex and the capsule. This procedure follows capsulorrhexis and serves to facilitate the removal of the lens material. The image does not show fluid injection or the separation process typical of hydrodissection.

 

Option C. Intraocular lens implantation: This step involves placing an intraocular lens (IOL) into the capsular bag once the lens material has been removed. In the image, there is no indication of an IOL being handled or inserted, as the focus is solely on manipulating the capsule itself, which precedes the IOL implantation in the surgical sequence.

 

Option D. Lens aspiration: Lens aspiration involves the removal of the lens cortex and nucleus, usually through suction or phacoemulsification, following the capsulorrhexis and hydrodissection steps. The image does not depict any equipment or actions associated with the aspiration of lens material, such as a phacoemulsification handpiece or suction device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capsulorrhexis is characterized by the creation of a controlled and continuous tear in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is essential for accessing and removing the lens material in cataract surgery. This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with a yellow question mark ? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner nuclear layer

 

The marked structure in the slide is the inner nuclear layer of the retina

 

  • Present between the outer plexiform layer and the inner plexiform layer.
  • Contains the cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and amacrine cells.
  • Dark stain.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

 

  • Image shows neovascularization in proliferative diabetic retinopathy, arising from optic nerve head.
  • Neovascularization of the disc (ND). and along large vessels, as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE) present.
  • Treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of ischaemic areas.
  • Aim is to reduce metabolic demand and prevent release of vasoproliferative factors.

 

 

Birdshot retinochoroidopathy (also known as birdshot chorioretinopathy, vitiliginous chorioretinitis, or simply birdshot uveitis) is a chronic, bilateral, posterior uveitis with characteristic yellow-white lesions in the fundus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mild Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - Characterized by microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages but does not feature neovascularization.

 

Option B. Severe Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - More extensive than mild, including hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and sometimes severe retinal ischemia, but still lacks neovascularization.

 

Option C. Birdshot Choroidopathy - Typically presents with distinctive yellow-white lesions in the retina, which are not apparent in the provided angiography images. This condition is an inflammatory process, not related to neovascularization seen in diabetic retinopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is the advanced stage of diabetic eye disease, marked by neovascularization, which requires aggressive treatment like laser photocoagulation to prevent severe visual loss. It is crucial for diabetics, particularly those with a long history or poorly controlled diabetes, to undergo regular eye examinations for early detection and management of diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atropine Sulfate eye ointment

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as the nonspecific supportive treatment in both bacterial as well as a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is utilized in the management of fungal corneal ulcers primarily to relieve symptoms like pain due to ciliary spasm and to prevent complications such as the formation of posterior synechiae. Atropine achieves this by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscles, thus providing a therapeutic benefit in the treatment of corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine e/d: Generally used to contract the pupil in glaucoma treatment, not appropriate for corneal ulcers as it can increase pain by causing ciliary spasm.

 

Option B. Lignocaine e/d: An anesthetic used for temporary pain relief but does not serve as adjuvant therapy in managing ulcers.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone e/d: A corticosteroid, generally avoided in fungal infections due to its potential to exacerbate infections by suppressing immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcers to relieve pain and prevent the formation of posterior synechiae by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscle.

questions.text: The following image indicates: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor palsy

 

The given image suggests oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

The central image shows the eyes in primary gaze where the patient's left eye has deviated down and out. There is also ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements, it can be seen that adduction, elevation, and depression are absent in the left eye.

 

All of these findings indicate oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis: This is due to the weakness of the levator muscle.
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out"): This is due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest: This is due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction: This is due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation: This is due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression: This is due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation: This is due to parasympathetic palsy.
  • Normal abduction: This is due to the intact lateral rectus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trochlear nerve palsy: Primarily affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical diplopia and head tilt but does not cause ptosis or pupil involvement.

 

Option B. Lateral rectus palsy: Would lead to medial deviation of the eye due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle, affecting horizontal eye movement.

 

Option C. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: Characterized by impairment of horizontal eye movements, particularly affecting the adduction of the eye on the side of the lesion, with nystagmus in the abducting eye, typically not involving the eyelid or pupil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor palsy involves multiple dysfunctions including ptosis, "down and out" eye position, and possibly a dilated pupil. Recognizing the full range of symptoms is critical for a correct diagnosis, indicating a comprehensive evaluation of cranial nerve III integrity.

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous steroids

 

  • Intravenous steroids are not used for the treatment of endophthalmitis.
  • Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.
  • Etiology: exogenous infection (trauma, surgery), endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis, secondary infections from surrounding structures.
  • Cardinal features: pain, lid swelling, diminished vision.
  • Maintain high index of suspicion, especially in postoperative cases, and treat empirically with antibiotics and steroids from the beginning.

 

Treatment

 

All cases are treated empirically with a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics and corticosteroids from the beginning. The aim is to maintain a high intraocular concentration of antibiotics throughout treatment.

 

  • Therapeutic regimen 
    • Topical antibiotics: Fortified cefazolin or vancomycin with gentamicin or amikacin.
    • Topical atropine: for cycloplegia.
    • Subconjunctival antibiotics: not frequently used.
    • Intravitreal antibiotics: The treatment of choice and are injected after taking vitreous aspirate for preparing smears and obtaining cultures. A combination of vancomycin and ceftazidime is preferred. Amikacin or gentamicin is used less frequently (risk of macular infarction). Simultaneous injection of dexamethasone is optional.
    • Intravitreal injection of amphotericin B: In suspected fungal aetiology, without the use of any adjunctive steroids.
    • Oral antifungals: Given, if fungal cultures are positive.
    • Vitrectomy: Hastens bacterial and fungal endophthalmitis recovery.
    • Corticosteroids: 
      • Some authorities recommend the combined use of corticosteroids from the outset (unless there is a strong clinical suspicion of a fungal aetiology in which case steroids should be withheld), while others prefer to wait for a confirmed positive clinical response to antibiotic therapy before administering steroids over the next 24–48 hours.
      • The rationale for corticosteroid therapy derives from its anti-inflammatory effects, leading to preservation of the ocular structures.
      • Routes of administration are:
        1. Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone
        2. Subconjunctival injection of dexamethasone
        3. Topical dexamethasone or predacetate
        4. Oral prednisolone
    • Patients need to be reviewed every 4–8 hours. The visual outcome depends on the duration between the onset of infection and institution of therapy, and the nature of the infecting organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A Intravitreal antibiotic injection: This is a standard treatment for endophthalmitis, involving direct administration of antibiotics into the eye to quickly achieve high intraocular concentrations, crucial for combating the infection.

 

Option C. Pars plana vitrectomy: Often recommended for severe cases, this surgical intervention can remove infectious agents and inflammatory debris directly from the vitreous, thereby reducing bacterial load and improving drug penetration.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotic: Used to provide high local concentrations of antibiotics at the site of infection, though not sufficient alone for severe cases, they support the main treatment regimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For endophthalmitis following ocular surgery, intravitreal antibiotics are crucial, while systemic steroids are generally avoided due to the risk of exacerbating the infection.

questions.text: All are causes for expanding blind spot, except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoplasia of optic disc

 

Expansion of blind spot is not seen in optic disc hypoplasia. Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly that presents due to the underdevelopment of the optic nerve. The optic disc is surrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring known as a "double-ring" sign. This condition does not typically lead to changes in the size of the blind spot, as it primarily affects the development of the optic nerve rather than its function related to the blind spot's expansion.

 

 

  • Physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma caused by the absence of photoreceptors in the region occupied by the optic disc.
  • Lesions affecting the optic disc region can expand the blind spot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. POAG: The rise in IOP in primary open-angle glaucoma causes pressure on the optic nerve head and consequent atrophy leading to expansion of the blindspot.

 

Option C. Papilledema: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling associated with raised intracranial pressure, and the edematous optic disc is swollen beyond its usual margins, causing the blind spot to enlarge.

 

Option D. Medullated nerve fibres: Medullated nerve fibers (optic disc medullation) is a condition of abnormal myelination of the nerve fibers of the retina, where myelination continues beyond lamina cribrosa and spreads into the retina beyond the optic disc. This leads to the expansion of the blind spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic disc hypoplasia, a congenital underdevelopment of the optic nerve, does not typically result in an expanding blind spot, unlike conditions like POAG, papilledema, and the presence of medullated nerve fibers, which can directly affect the structure or function of the area surrounding the optic disc.

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ptosis of right eye

 

The patient has ptosis of the right eye. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea. Ptosis is generally unilateral, in over 70% of individuals. The drooping in this case is significant enough to cover a portion of the pupil, thereby obstructing part of the visual field, which is characteristic of ptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entropion of right eye: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid margin, not observed in the provided image.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos of right eye: Refers to the inability to close the eyelids completely, not evident here.

 

Option D. Exophthalmos of left eye: Characterized by the protrusion of the eyeball, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis, particularly of the type seen in this patient, is typically caused by a dysfunction or disconnection of the levator muscle or its aponeurosis, either congenital or acquired.

 

Types:

 

 

Note: Pseudoptosis is apparent but not true drooping of the eyelid. Causes include lack of support of the lids by the globe (orbital volume deficit like an artificial eye, microphthalmos, or enophthalmos), contralateral lid retraction, ipsilateral hypotropia, brow ptosis, or dermatochalasis.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collar stud appearance  

 

The provided image depicts the right fundus of a patient, which indicates the presence of choroidal melanoma.

 

  • Angiography of the lesion: shows a distinct "double circulation" pattern, which represents the internal circulation within the tumor and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina.
  • On B-scan: pathognomonic feature called the "collar stud appearance" is visible. This appearance refers to a raised, dome-shaped tumor with a collar-like thickening at the base, caused by the accumulation of melanin and the infiltration of inflammatory cells at the tumor base.

 

 

Choroidal melanoma is a type of cancer that originates in the choroid, which is the vascular layer of the eye located between the retina and the sclera. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and can lead to visual impairment and even metastasis to other organs. Therefore, it is crucial to diagnose and manage it promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: Typically associated with central serous retinopathy, showing a smoke-like leakage of fluid under the retina.

 

Option B. Inkblot appearance: Another pattern seen in central serous retinopathy where fluid leaks in a blot-like fashion.

 

Option D. Double circulation: While this feature can be seen in angiography of choroidal melanoma, it does not describe the ultrasonography appearance, which is specifically asked in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: SAFE strategy for trachoma includes all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evaluation of control program

 

In the SAFE strategy, ‘E’ stands for Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation.

 

Effective interventions for trachoma blindness have been demonstrated in developing nations using the SAFE strategy –

 

  • Surgery (S): Performed to correct trichiasis, which is the inward turning of the eyelashes that can lead to corneal damage and blindness. This intervention helps prevent further damage to the cornea.
  • Antibiotics (A): Used to treat the infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Mass drug administration is typically used in endemic areas to reduce the prevalence of the infection.
  • Facial cleanliness (F): Encouraged to reduce transmission of the bacterium among community members, especially children who are more susceptible to infection.
  • Environmental improvement (E): Focuses on improving living conditions, such as increasing access to clean water and better sanitation facilities, to reduce the spread of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

 

  • The superior oblique muscle is responsible for three actions: intorsion, depression, and abduction.
  • Each eye has six extraocular muscles: four recti muscles and two oblique muscles.
  • The recti muscles are the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral rectus.
  • The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator.
  • The tendon's oblique direction gives it a rotator effect, resulting in intorsion, as well as depression and abduction.
  • These muscles control both unilateral and binocular movements of the eye.
  • Unilateral eye movements are called Ductions.
  • Bilateral eye movements are called Versions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to OPD with the complaints of glare during night drives. He had undergone cataract surgery 1 year back. The best-corrected visual acuity in RE = 6/12 and LE = 6/9. No improvement with pinhole. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior capsular opacification

 

Posterior capsular Opacification is a common complication that can occur after cataract surgery. It is also known as "after" or "secondary" cataract. The condition is caused by residual opaque lens matter that may persist after surgery or by the proliferative type that develops from left-out anterior epithelial cells.

 

 

The surgery usually involves the removal of the lens through a small incision in the cornea. In extracapsular extraction of the lens, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ. In many cases, these remnants are fine, forming a thin membrane that is difficult to see. However, in some cases, especially when the cataract was not mature, some soft, clear cortex sticks to the capsule.

 

Posterior capsular pacification can present in different forms, including thickened posterior capsule, dense membranous after cataract or Soemmering's ring, or Elschnig's pearls. Soemmering's ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract formed behind the iris, enclosed between the two layers of capsule. Elschnig's pearls refer to vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells clustered like soap bubbles along the posterior capsule.

 

 

If the remnants lie in the pupillary area, they can form a dense membrane that impairs vision. This membranous form of posterior capsular Opacification can cause vision to be blurry, hazy, or cloudy. If the previous operation has been followed by iritis, exudates also adhere to the lens remnants and organize, thus contributing a fibrous membrane in addition.

 

The rate of posterior capsule Opacification varies with the patient's age, surgeon, surgical technique, type of intraocular lens used, and duration after surgery. Patients who are younger and those who undergo phacoemulsification may have a lower risk of developing posterior capsular Opacification.

 

Overall, posterior capsular Opacification is a treatable condition that can be resolved through a simple laser procedure called Nd YAG Laser posterior capsulotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystoid macular edema: This involves swelling in the central retina and is often associated with decreased vision and possibly distorted central vision, not primarily glare.

 

Option B. Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy: This condition involves swelling and opacities in the cornea following cataract surgery, characterized by significant visual impairment and painful blisters on the cornea, not just glare.

 

Option C. ARMD - Age-Related Macular Degeneration: ARMD affects the macula and leads to central vision loss, which would not typically present primarily as glare or be directly associated with recent cataract surgery outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior capsular opacification after cataract surgery can mimic the symptoms of the original cataract and cause significant visual impairment, primarily glare and blurred vision. It is treatable with a simple laser procedure known as Nd YAG laser posterior capsulotomy.

questions.text: A patient underwent LASIK for myopia and now is undergoing cataract surgery. What is the formula used for lens power calculation in this patient?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haigis-L  

 

  • The Haigis-L regression formula is used for lens power calculation in patients undergoing cataract surgery with a past history of LASIK for myopia.
  • Corneal refractive surgery significantly affects the IOL power required, making standard IOL calculations unsuitable.
  • Several methods of calculating corneal refractive power are used, such as the double-K method, Masket and modified Masket, and Haigis-L formulas.
  • The Haigis-L regression formula uses statistical data to facilitate calculation on post-refractive surgery eyes using only standard inputs.
  • It may be prudent to utilize more than one method of IOL calculation.

 

NEWER IOL POWER CALCULATION FORMULAE FOR POST REFRACTIVE SURGERY PATIENTS ARE –

 

  • Wang-Koch-Maloney
  • Shammas
  • Haigis-L
  • Galilei
  • Potvin-Hill Pentacam
  • Barrett True K No History      

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK 1 and Option B. SRK 2: These are older formulas that do not account for post-refractive surgery changes in corneal curvature and are less accurate in such cases.

 

Option C. Hoffer Q: While useful for eyes with shorter axial lengths, this formula also does not specifically adjust for the changes induced by corneal refractive surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who have had previous corneal refractive surgery like LASIK, specialized IOL calculation formulas such as Haigis-L should be used to ensure accurate lens power calculation for cataract surgery. This formula specifically addresses the altered corneal parameters to provide a more precise refractive outcome.

questions.text: The spectacles shown in the image are not used for the management of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypermetropia

 

The image shows a bifocal spectacle that is made of lenses with two different optical powers (upper half for distant vision and lower half for near vision). Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, primarily affects near vision, necessitating correction that provides a uniform optical adjustment across the entire lens surface to assist with close vision tasks, rather than segmented correction like in bifocals.

 

Other Options:

 

Bifocal spectacles are typically used for treating following conditions:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifocal spectacles are not typically used for treating hypermetropia, which generally requires a uniform optical correction across the entire lens to aid in near tasks. Bifocals are instead beneficial in conditions requiring simultaneous correction for near and far vision, such as presbyopia, or specific needs following surgical interventions like in aphakia and pediatric pseudophakia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuromyelitis optica

 

The most probable diagnosis is neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

 

NMO is a demyelinating autoimmune disease that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. Patients with NMO can present with recurrent episodes of optic neuritis, which can result in decreased visual acuity, as well as myelitis, which can cause weakness, sensory loss, and bladder dysfunction.

 

The patient's history of recurrent episodes of diminution of vision that recovers on treatment with steroids is consistent with optic neuritis, which is a common presenting feature of NMO. The history of transverse myelitis also supports a diagnosis of NMO, as myelitis is a common feature of the disease.

 

Management of acute attacks:

 

  • High-dose glucocorticoids
  • Plasma exchange.

 

Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses:

 

  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Rituximab
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Azathioprine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spastic quadriplegia: This is a genetic disorder affecting motor functions and does not involve optic neuritis or transverse myelitis.

 

Option B. Subacute combined degeneration: Typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency affecting the spinal cord, but not specifically linked with optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis (MS): While MS can present with symptoms similar to NMO, including optic neuritis and spinal cord involvement, the pattern of attacks and the severity of symptoms in the context of transverse myelitis point more specifically to NMO, especially considering the distinct pathophysiology and antibody profiles (e.g., anti-aquaporin-4 antibodies).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuromyelitis optica should be considered in patients presenting with recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, especially when there is a good response to steroid treatment. Distinguishing NMO from multiple sclerosis is crucial, as treatment and prognosis differ significantly between these conditions.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drusen  

 

  • Drusen, also called colloid bodies, are extracellular deposits located at the interface between the Retinal Pigmentary Epithelium and Bruch membrane.
  • Drusen are numerous, minute, whitish, refractile spots with pigmented margins, mainly involving the posterior pole.
  • They are seen in senile macular degeneration and Doyne's honeycomb dystrophy.
  • The material of which they are composed has a broad range of constituents and is thought to be derived from immune-mediated and metabolic processes in the retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • The precise role of drusen in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is unclear.
  • However, drusen are positively associated with the size of lesions and the presence or absence of associated pigmentary abnormalities.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hard exudates: Well-defined, bright yellow deposits of extravasated fluid rich in fibrin and proteins. These hyaline or lipid deposits are generally seen as a cluster around a group of leaking microaneurysms. Commonly seen in macular area, in the outer plexiform layer.

 

Option C. Cotton-wool spots: Composed of accumulations of neuronal debris within the nerve fibre layer.

 

Option D. Macular edema: Accumulation of excess fluid in the extracellular space within the retina in the macular area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drusen are distinct, granular deposits at the interface between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane, commonly associated with age-related macular degeneration and can be an early sign of the disease.

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral and upward gaze

 

Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear nerve palsy, not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

 

Signs of oculomotor nerve palsy

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ptosis Occurs due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

 

Option B. Mid-dilated pupil: Results from paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle, leading to unopposed dilation by the sympathetic innervation.

 

Option C. Loss of light reflex: Occurs because the parasympathetic fibers controlling pupillary constriction are affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Oculomotor nerve palsy typically causes an "down and out" gaze due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, not a "lateral and upward" gaze, which would instead suggest trochlear nerve involvement.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

 

The National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey conducted from 2015 to 2019 revealed that untreated cataract is the leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment (MSVI). MSVI is characterized by a presenting visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye despite available correction. Visual impairment and blindness are frequently observed in individuals who are 50 years old and above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Refractive errors are the leading cause of MSVI in patients aged 49 years and below.

 

Options C and Option D: Glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy account for a very low number of visual impairment cases in patients aged 50 years and above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence of untreated cataracts as a leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment emphasizes the need for effective public health strategies focusing on eye health screenings and accessible cataract surgery to reduce the burden of preventable blindness and visual impairment.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cataract

 

  • Cataract is not a common ocular manifestation of dengue infection.
  • Dengue infection can have various manifestations in different organ systems, primarily characterized by inflammation and bleeding.
  • Until recently, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection, apart from retro-orbital pain.
  • The potential pathogenic mechanisms for dengue-related eye involvement may include direct viral effects on the eye, immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Common in dengue due to increased fragility of blood vessels and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Uveitis: While less common, uveitis can occur in dengue fever as part of a systemic immune response to the infection.

 

Option D. Retinal hemorrhage: This is a direct consequence of the hemorrhagic tendency in dengue fever, related to thrombocytopenia and vascular fragility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

 

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis.
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

 

  • The clinical scenario described is due to right superior rectus palsy.
  • The three-step test, also called the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, can help diagnose which muscle is paralyzed in acquired hypertropia. It involves using the cover-uncover test and Maddox rod to measure deviation in different head positions.
  • The three-step test can also diagnose inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy, but it's not reliable for multiple paretic muscles or restrictive strabismus.
  • In patients with inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist, the three-step test can distinguish between true or simulated superior rectus palsy.

 

Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:

 

Step 1. Which eye is hypotropic?

 

The eye hypotropic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.

 

  • Right superior rectus
  • Right inferior oblique
  • Left inferior rectus
  • Left superior oblique

 

Step 2. Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?

 

The hypotropia increases in right gaze.

 

Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:

 

  • Left superior oblique
  • Right superior rectus

 

Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?

 

The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis typically leads to hypertropia and excyclotorsion, not hypotropia.

 

Option C. Right inferior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis would not result in the described pattern of hypotropia.

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique: Incorrect, since paralysis here does not explain the increase in hypotropia with right head tilt and right gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three-step test is a vital diagnostic tool in strabismus evaluations to identify which extraocular muscle is paretic based on the changes in eye position with head tilt and gaze direction. In this scenario, the findings align with a right superior rectus muscle palsy, consistent with its role in elevating the right eye especially during right gaze and head tilt to the right.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the eye: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Canal of Petit

 

Canal of Petit, aka Spatia Zonularis / Zonular spaces, is a cleft or sacculated canal surrounding the lens between the posterior of the zonule of Zinn fibers and aqueous humor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egger's Line: This is a reference line used in gonioscopy to denote the anterior limit of the trabecular meshwork, not directly related to the lens or zonular apparatus.

 

Option B. Lens Capsule: This is the clear, membrane-like structure surrounding the lens itself, not the space around it.

 

Option C. Canal of Hannover: This is another anatomical feature in the eye associated with the zonular fibers but refers to a different part of the zonular apparatus than the Canal of Petit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Canal of Petit is an essential structure in the anatomy of the eye, playing a critical role in the stability and function of the lens. Its correct identification and understanding are pivotal in eye health management and surgical procedures involving the lens and surrounding structures.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below. The given FFA is characteristic of which of the following? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macular ischemia

 

  • The FFA image shows features suggestive of macular ischemia (see the images below).
  • The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyper fluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage in the disc region and elsewhere.

 

 

  • The FFA is showing enlarged fovea avascular zone arrow (white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow).
  • Both of which are suggestive of macular ischemia which when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient points towards diabetic macular ischemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macular edema: shows the characteristic petaloid appearance.

 

Option C. Submacular/subretinal hemorrhage: obscure the choroidal dye visualization in the corresponding area, appearing similar to capillary non-perfusion but spreads across vascular zones without a defined pattern. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however, be visualized.

 

Option D. Premacular hemorrhage/ vitreous hemorrhage: obscure the visualization of even retinal vasculature and would appear as a region of hypo fluorescence with no retinal vasculature visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macular ischemia in diabetic patients can be identified in FFA images by an enlarged foveal avascular zone and visible areas of capillary non-perfusion, key indicators of decreased vascular supply to the macula.

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner plexiform layer

 

The inner plexiform layer is marked in the above histological image of the retina.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inner plexiform layer of the retina is a crucial site for synaptic activity among various retinal cells, playing a key role in the preprocessing of visual information before it is sent to the brain. Recognizing this layer and understanding its function are important for comprehending the overall neural circuitry of the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus

 

Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF): pair of tracts that interconnect CN VI and CN III nuclei. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) occurs due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which is responsible for coordinating horizontal eye movements. The command for left gaze originates from the right cerebral cortex and travels to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). From there, an output goes to the left VI nerve nucleus, which supplies the left lateral rectus muscle, causing abduction. Another output from the left PPRF goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF, causing the right eye to adduct.

 

If there is a lesion in the right MLF, it leads to the failure of adduction of the right eye. However, the left eye abducts normally. This is the classic presentation of INO.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th Nerve nucleus: A lesion here would result in an inability to abduct the eye on the same side, not INO.

 

Option C. Pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF): A lesion here would typically affect both the initiation of gaze to the ipsilateral side and horizontal gaze coordination, leading to symptoms different from typical INO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of internuclear ophthalmoplegia involves a failure of adduction in the affected eye due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Recognizing this pathway and its role in horizontal eye movement coordination is crucial for diagnosing and understanding the clinical manifestations of INO.

choices.text: Regeneration is limited to the limbus.
