questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bowman's membrane regenerates.

 

The false statement about the corneal epithelium is B, stating that "Bowman's membrane regenerates." This is incorrect as Bowman's membrane is an acellular layer composed of collagen fibers and, once damaged, does not regenerate. The other statements regarding the corneal epithelium are true and align with the anatomical and functional characteristics of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regeneration is limited to the limbus: This is true as limbal stem cells are key to the regeneration of the corneal epithelium.

 

Option C. Lined by stratified squamous epithelium: True, this describes the specific cell type forming the corneal epithelium.

 

Option D. Apical cells have microvilli: Also true, the microvilli increase the surface area for better adhesion of the tear film, enhancing eye lubrication and protection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roenne's nasal step

 

  • Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.
  • Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field.

 

Roenne’s nasal step

 

 

  • Early glaucomatous changes:
    • Increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to >0.4
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin
    • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes:
    • Marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more)
    • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim
    • Nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting
    • Pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.
    • If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bayonetting: This refers to the appearance of blood vessels on the optic disc where the vessels appear to sharply bend or 'bayonet' due to the structural changes in the optic disc from glaucomatous damage, particularly as the neuroretinal rim thins and the cup enlarges.

 

Option C. Increased cup-disc ratio: A hallmark of glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve, where the optic cup enlarges relative to the overall disc, often exceeding a ratio of 0.5, which is considered abnormal and suggestive of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Baring of nasal arteries: This describes the exposure or baring of the nasal retinal arteries as a result of thinning of the nerve fiber layer in glaucoma. It is a less commonly described feature compared to others but can occur as part of the broader pattern of optic nerve head changes in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roenne's nasal step, while indicative of the functional impact of glaucoma, does not represent a direct observation of the optic disc but is rather a manifestation of the disease's effect on the visual field.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Removal of the foreign body

 

The image shows an eye with a metallic foreign body causing a penetrating injury. In such cases, immediate removal of the foreign body is not recommended as an initial step because doing so may exacerbate the injury or lead to complications such as infection or further mechanical damage to the eye structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Proper Initial Steps Include:
 

Option B. Check for visual acuity: This helps assess the extent of damage to the eye's visual function and provides a baseline for future comparisons.

 

Option C. Give antibiotics: Prophylactic treatment to prevent infection, especially considering the risk introduced by the foreign object.

 

Option D. Do primary survey: Ensures that the patient's overall health and other potential life-threatening conditions are addressed (part of the ABCDE approach - Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure).

 

Further Management:

 

CT scan: To precisely locate the foreign body and any possible penetration into the orbital or cranial cavities, helping plan for surgical intervention.

 

Avoid MRI: Due to the risk of movement of the metallic object, which can cause more damage.

 

Surgical exploration and repair in the operating theatre: To safely remove the foreign body under controlled conditions, minimizing risk of further damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ocular injuries involving foreign bodies, immediate removal is not advised due to the potential for further damage. Initial steps should focus on assessment, stabilization, and prevention of infection, followed by careful planning and execution of the foreign body removal under appropriate surgical conditions.

questions.text: Identify the ‘1’ in the picture: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

  • Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina centred around the fovea with the formation of tiny cyst-like cavities forming a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography.
  • CME develops due to leakage of fluid following breakdown of inner blood-retinal barrier (i.e., leakage from the retinal capillaries).
  • It is associated with a number of disorders, including postoperative complications following cataract extraction and penetrating keratoplasty, retinal vascular disorders (e.g., diabetic retinopathy and central retinal vein occlusion), intraocular inflammations (e.g., pars planitis, posterior uveitis, Behcet disease), side effects of drugs (e.g., following use of adrenaline eyedrops, especially for aphakic glaucoma, and retinal dystrophies (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa).
  • Clinical manifestations of CME include visual loss, which may be initially minimal to moderate and un-associated with other symptoms, but can progress to permanent decrease in vision if edema persists.
  • CME is best examined with a fundus contact lens on slit-lamp or +90D lens, and typically presents a "Honey-comb appearance" of macula due to multiple cystoid oval spaces on ophthalmoscopy.

 

 

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography demonstrates leakage and accumulation of dye in the macular region, which in a well-established case presents a "flower petal appearance".

 

 

Cystoid macular edema (CME) and central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) are two conditions that can affect the macula, the central part of the retina. Here is a table comparing the two conditions:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macular Hole: This would appear as a dark or black spot in the center of the macula due to a full-thickness opening in the retina, which is not observed in this image.

 

Option C. Smoke stack pattern: This pattern would be typical of central serous chorioretinopathy and is characterized by a well-defined, localized leakage point causing fluid to ascend vertically, not seen here.

 

Option D. Age related Macular Degeneration: Typically shows drusen, geographic atrophy, or neovascularization, none of which are evident in this fluorescein angiography image as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) often presents with a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography due to pooling of dye in cystic spaces of the macula and is associated with various underlying conditions affecting the vascular integrity of the retina.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypopyon  

 

The finding seen in the image is hypopyon.

 

  • Hypopyon is an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, typically seen in the lower part of the chamber as a whitish exudate.
  • In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungus can penetrate into the anterior chamber without causing a perforation.
  • Hypopyon associated with anterior uveitis is immobile because of the high fibrin content in the exudate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Hyphema is a hemorrhage in the anterior chamber. It commonly occurs after a blunt ocular injury. The bleeding is from the iris root or ciliary body face. The blood settles inferiorly forming a fluid level.

 

 

Option B: Aqueous flare refers to the haziness of the normally clear fluid in the anterior chamber. It reflects the presence of protein due to the breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier. The presence of flare indicates active inflammation.

 

Option C: Arlt line is the scarring on the conjunctiva in the area of sulcus subtarsalis. It can be a single line, irregularly shaped, or star-shaped. Common causes are trachoma, healed traumatic wounds, or surgical scars.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.

questions.text: Identify the condition: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor nerve palsy

 

The given image suggests a diagnosis of oculomotor nerve palsy because of the following features:

 

  • Left eye is deviating downwards and outwards.
  • Left eyelid is showing ptosis.
  • Left eye is unable to move upwards, downwards, or inwards towards the nose, indicating a lack of adduction, elevation, and depression.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position (“down and out”) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Normal abduction due to the intact lateral rectus.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial rectus palsy: Incorrect because. Medial rectus palsy specifically affects the ability of the eye to adduct (move inward toward the nose). If only the medial rectus were paretic, you would primarily observe limitation in horizontal inward movement of the affected eye without the associated ptosis, "down and out" positioning, or pupil involvement seen in the provided images. These broader symptoms indicate involvement of multiple muscles, which is characteristic of oculomotor nerve palsy, not isolated medial rectus palsy.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) palsy affects the superior oblique muscle, which primarily results in problems with eye rotation and vertical gaze, especially when looking downward and inward. Patients often present with vertical diplopia (double vision), head tilt away from the side of the lesion to compensate for the misalignment, and no ptosis or pupillary involvement. The symptoms and the eye movement limitations shown in the images do not match those typically associated with trochlear nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) palsy results in failure of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to an inability to abduct the eye (move outward). Patients with this condition will have the affected eye positioned inward (medially) due to unopposed action of the medial rectus. This condition would not cause the ptosis or the "down and out" appearance nor the wide range of motion impairments displayed in the images, such as the inability to move the eye upward or downward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor nerve palsy significantly affects eye movement and eyelid function due to its role in innervating most of the extraocular muscles as well as lifting the eyelid. Diagnosis often involves a comprehensive evaluation of eye movement patterns, eyelid function, and pupil response, along with investigations to determine underlying causes. Treatment focuses on addressing the root cause and managing symptoms to protect eye function and quality of life.

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Staphyloma

 

High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the ocular tissue, thereby resulting in a staphyloma.

 

Staphyloma: It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

 

 

Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.

 

Types of Staphylomas     -

 

 

Note:

 

The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.

 

The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoconus: This condition involves a progressive thinning and coning of the cornea, leading to visual distortion, but it is not typically associated with glaucoma.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia: A severe form of vitamin A deficiency leading to corneal softening. The association between keratomalacia and glaucoma is not typical, as keratomalacia results primarily from nutritional deficiencies.

 

Option D. Granular dystrophy: A type of corneal dystrophy characterized by the accumulation of granular deposits in the cornea. It is a genetically inherited condition, unrelated to the thinning caused by glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphyloma, particularly anterior and ciliary types, can develop due to high intraocular pressure in glaucoma, leading to the protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weakened cornea or sclera.

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marcus Gunn pupil  

 

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage.
  • A defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye can cause a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test.
  • The Marcus Gunn pupil is observed when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye and the affected pupil dilates instead of remaining constricted.
  • Seen in optic neuritis.
  • Earliest indictor of optic nerve disease (Retrobulbar neuritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adie tonic pupil is a Sluggishly reacting mid-dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

 

Option C. Argyll-Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation, which is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus.

 

Option D. Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marcus Gunn pupil, or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage, and is identified using the swinging flashlight test.

questions.text:
Which of the following has familial inheritance? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Retinitis pigmentosa
  3. Муоріа
  4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All the above conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) have a familial inheritance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stereopsis test

 

The test shown in the above image is Titmus stereotest, which is done to test for stereopsis (perception of depth).

 

  • Patients are shown a picture of a housefly for children and circular patterns for adults.
  • The picture is held about 16 inches in front of the patient's eyes.
  • Patients are asked to wear polarized glasses during the test.
  • Normal perception of depth will cause the housefly to appear as a 3D image above the plane.
  • Patients will attempt to pinch the wings of the housefly in the air, above the plane of the image, if perception of depth is normal.
  • Defective perception of depth will cause the image to appear as a normal 2D image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ocular deviation: This refers to misalignment of the eyes, typically tested with cover tests or Hirschberg test, not the Titmus stereotest.

 

Option C. Refractive errors: These are assessed with vision tests using an eye chart, not stereopsis tests.

 

Option D. Colour Blindness: This is assessed using color vision tests like the Ishihara test, not related to depth perception tests like the Titmus stereotest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Titmus stereotest evaluates stereopsis or depth perception, an essential aspect of binocular vision, allowing for the three-dimensional interpretation of the world necessary for various activities and indicating healthy, cooperative eye function.

questions.text: Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked with the question mark in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior colliculus

 

The highlighted muscle is the medial rectus, which is supplied by the oculomotor nerve. The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve is situated at the level of the superior colliculus. The oculomotor nerve arises from a nuclear complex that includes the oculomotor nucleus and Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus. The oculomotor nucleus is comprised of several groups of large motor neurons that innervate the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus in dorsoventral order. Additionally, a column of cells located medially innervates the contralateral superior rectus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior olivary: This is part of the auditory pathway and has no involvement in eye muscle control.

 

Option B. Inferior colliculus: Also part of the auditory pathway, located in the midbrain but not involved in motor control of eye movements.

 

Option D. Fascial colliculus: This term is likely a typographical error for "facial colliculus," which refers to a structure in the brainstem associated with the facial nerve, not the oculomotor nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve, responsible for innervating the medial rectus muscle among others, is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain. This is crucial for understanding the neural control of eye movements, particularly in how various components of the eye are coordinated for proper visual alignment and focus.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the given image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6th nerve palsy

 

  • The left eye of the patient has limitation of movement laterally.
  • The sixth cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus. In case of lateral rectus palsy,
    • ﻿﻿There is a convergent squint with limitation of movement outwards, and the face is turned towards the paralysed side.
    • ﻿﻿Homonymous diplopia occurs on looking to the paralysed side.
    • ﻿﻿The images are on the same level and erect, becoming more separated on looking more towards the paralysed side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve palsy:

 

  • Oculomotor nerve supplies all intraocular muscles (sphincter and dilator pupillae) and extraocular muscles (LPS, MR, SR, IR, IO) except lateral rectus and superior oblique.
  • Its paralysis results in
    • Ptosis - Due to the paralysis of LPS
    • Down and out eye (due to unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique)
    • Loss of accommodation (due to paralysis of ciliary muscle)
    • Loss of light reflex
    • Dilated pupil
    • Crossed diplopia

 

Option C. Bell’s palsy:

 

  • Bell palsy is the most common cause of peripheral facial palsy.

 

 

Option D. Horner’s syndrome:

 

  • Sympathetic denervation of face:
    • Ptosis (slight drooping of eyelid: superior tarsal muscle)
    • Miosis (pupil constriction)
    • Anhidrosis (absence of sweating)
    • Flushing of affected side of face

 

Educational Objective:

 

6th nerve palsy is characterized by an inability to abduct the eye, typically presenting as inward turning of the eye due to unopposed medial rectus action, leading to horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking towards the side of the affected nerve. This diagnosis is crucial in patients presenting with lateral gaze limitation following trauma, raised intracranial pressure, or an ischemic event.

questions.text:
Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Phenylephrine
  2. 1% Pilocarpine
  3. 0.1% Pilocarpine
  4. Cocaine 0.5%
  5. Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

Pilocarpine is used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils.

 

2. 1% Pilocarpine

 

 

3. 0.1% Pilocarpine

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Phenylephrine: This is a sympathomimetic agent that typically dilates the pupil and is not used for differentiating causes of fixed dilation.

 

4. Cocaine 0.5%: Cocaine tests for anisocoria primarily in the context of Horner’s syndrome. It blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, failing to dilate a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic chain lesion.

 

 

Note - Cocaine and 1% hydroxy amphetamine are used to evaluate anisocoria in smaller pupil.

 

 

5. Epinephrine: Similar to phenylephrine, epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain, photophobia and redness of the right eye since 2 days. He gave a history of injury by a leaf, to the same eye, 5 days back. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal corneal ulcer

 

The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter or injury by animal tail.

 

A very characteristic feature of fungal corneal ulcer is that the Signs are much more than Symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior uveitis: This involves inflammation of the middle layer of the eye, which can cause pain and redness but does not involve the specific corneal changes seen in fungal ulcers.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis: An inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, typically causing redness and discharge, not the specific features of a corneal ulcer.

 

Option D. Corneal laceration: While also a result of trauma, lacerations would generally present immediately post-injury with sharp, distinct cuts, rather than developing signs of infection such as those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fungal corneal ulcer should be considered when a patient presents with eye symptoms following trauma involving vegetative or organic material. Key diagnostic features include a greyish-white ulcer with feathery margins, potentially accompanied by a hypopyon, and absence of corneal vascularization.

questions.text: What is the first step in the management of an 18-month-old child with both eyes deviated medially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refractive error testing

 

In children, who present with a convergent squint, the first step is to check the visual acuity and estimate the error of refraction.

 

  • When the child presents, the distant vision is recorded and atropine 1% eye ointment, 3 times a day, is prescribed for three days.
  • After 3 days, the error of refraction is estimated by retinoscopy.
  • Fundoscopy is done to rule out retinoblastoma, and any other pathology
  • The angle of squint is measured and full spectacle correction is ordered for constant use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forced ductions test: Used to check if the eye muscles move normally or are restricted, more relevant in cases where physical obstruction or muscle entrapment is suspected.

 

Option B. Examination under anesthesia: May be necessary for a comprehensive examination in uncooperative children, but it is not the first step.

 

Option D. Examination of fundus: Important for ruling out intraocular causes of squint such as retinoblastoma, but it follows the refractive assessment in priority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first management step for a child presenting with a convergent squint is to test for refractive errors. This helps to identify any need for optical correction which might resolve or reduce the squint, thereby improving the visual development and alignment of the eyes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) After cataract

 

(SYNONYMS: POSTERIOR CAPSULAR OPACIFICATION/SECOND CATARACT)

 

  • Elschnig's pearls are a type of after cataract, a delayed complication of cataract surgery.
  • They are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles, along the posterior capsule of the lens.

 

Types of after cataract:

 

  • ﻿﻿Thin membranous after-cataract (thickened posterior capsule)
  • ﻿﻿Dense membranous after-cataract
  • ﻿﻿Soemmering ring: peripheral thick ring of opacity between 2 capsules.
  • ﻿Elschnig's pearls

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Irvine-Gass syndrome:

 

  • Postoperative cystoid macular edema classically described as vitreous touch syndrome.
  • Can occur upto 6 months post cataract surgery.
  • Resolves on its own.
  • Non resolving Irvine Gass syndrome is treated with topical NSAID eye drops, intra and periocular steroid injection and intravitreal Anti-VEGF injection.

 

Option C. Endophthalmitis:

 

  • Caused by an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becoming trapped within the capsular bag
  • Characterized by pain and redness
  • Delayed complication
  • Treatment is removal of entire IOL-Bag complex along with vitrectomy and secondary IOL implantation – either sclera fixation / iris claw IOL / Anterior chamber IOL.

 

Option D. Uveitis-glaucoma-hyphema syndrome:

 

  • Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously
  • Seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation
  • Also seen when foldable hydrophilic IOL is implanted in ciliary sulcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior capsular opacification or after cataract is a common post-surgical complication following cataract surgery, characterized by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells leading to opacification of the posterior capsule. This can diminish vision and may require further treatment, typically a simple laser procedure called a YAG capsulotomy to restore clarity to the visual axis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with complaint of sudden diminishing vision. On examination, relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the right eye and the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. MRI brain and orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • The presented clinical features suggest optic neuritis, which is characterized by sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss along with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • The recommended investigations for optic neuritis include MRI brain and orbit, screening for circulating MOG and NMO antibodies, and checking blood sugar levels.
  • Brain MRI is suggested in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis, as there is a high probability of developing multiple sclerosis.
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis that can occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. The presence of MOG and MO antibodies can diagnose the condition.
  • Reason for checking blood glucose level-
    • If it turns out to be optic neuritis, blood glucose levels should be measured as steroids are mainstay treatment modality
  • Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates RAPD, is a characteristic sign of optic neuritis. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test, where the eyes' response to light is observed by swinging the flashlight multiple times.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Thyroid profile: This is generally not directly relevant to acute visual changes associated with optic neuritis unless there is a suspicion of thyroid eye disease, which typically presents with other distinctive signs such as exophthalmos, eyelid retraction, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of sudden visual loss with RAPD, it is crucial to perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. MRI of the brain and orbits, along with specific antibody tests for MOG and NMO, provide critical information for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of optic neuritis and related conditions. Monitoring blood sugar levels is also essential, especially in the context of potential steroid therapy.

questions.text: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor.
  • It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
  • The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:
    1. Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
    2. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
    3. Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)
    4. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

 

Note: Most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland: Adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can occur in various glands in the body, including the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by slow growth and the tendency to invade nearby structures.

 

Option C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is another type of malignant tumor that can affect the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by a combination of mucin-secreting and squamous (epidermoid) cells.

 

Option D. Malignant mixed tumor: Malignant mixed tumor, also known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma, occurs when a previously benign pleomorphic adenoma transforms into a malignant tumor. It is less common than pleomorphic adenoma but represents a more aggressive form of lacrimal gland tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is usually benign and arises from the glandular tissue. It can sometimes have a mixture of cell types, hence the name "pleomorphic."

questions.text: An intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done thereafter? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Never replaced

 

In the case of a successful and uneventful intraocular lens (IOL) implantation during cataract surgery, there is typically no need to replace the IOL. These lenses are designed to be permanent solutions that do not require routine replacement. Modern IOLs are made from durable materials that are meant to last a lifetime without degrading or causing adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IOL replaced every 10 years: There is no routine schedule for replacing IOLs as they are designed to last a lifetime.

 

Option C. Replaced when secondary cataract develops: Secondary cataract (or posterior capsule opacification) can often be treated with a simple laser procedure called a posterior capsulotomy, not by replacing the IOL.

 

Option D. Replaced when presbyopia develops: Presbyopia is related to the lens of the eye and loss of its elasticity, affecting near vision; IOLs implanted during cataract surgery do not correct presbyopia inherent to aging, but specific types of IOLs can be chosen to address presbyopia at the time of surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

 

  • Incorrect IOL placed-Incorrect power or Incorrect Type
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma
In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot


Initial indications of glaucoma in perimetry involve a widespread narrowing of isopters and the appearance of a blockage within the blind spot.

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic test used to assess a person's visual field.

 

Static Perimetry: Traditional method involving fixed stimulus points presented on a static grid. Goldmann perimetry and Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer are common devices for static perimetry.

 

Kinetic Perimetry: Moving stimuli are used to determine the boundaries of the visual field. Useful for mapping the extent of peripheral vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Kinetic perimetry involves moving a stimulus across the visual field to map the boundaries of each isopter. It is not specifically used for quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma; static perimetry is more commonly used for this purpose

 

Option B: In static perimetry, various light spots of different intensities are presented in different locations but do not move across the visual field. The statement in B inaccurately describes kinetic perimetry

 

Option C: While optic nerve head abnormalities are a critical diagnostic feature of glaucoma, visual field defects can exist without clear corresponding optic nerve changes, especially in early or mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: What was ETDRS study related to? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diabetic Macular edema

 

  • Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a clinical trial.
  • The study investigated the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
  • The study demonstrated that focal photocoagulation was beneficial in treating diabetic macular edema.
  • The study recommended that eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal artery occlusion: Not the focus of the ETDRS; this condition involves sudden, painless vision loss due to an occlusion in the central retinal artery.

 

Option C. Primary open angle glaucoma: Not related to the ETDRS, which did not address glaucoma treatments or outcomes.

 

Option D. Non-infectious uveitis: Also unrelated to the ETDRS, as the study was specific to diabetic retinopathy and macular edema, not inflammatory eye diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ETDRS study established the beneficial effects of photocoagulation in treating diabetic macular edema, recommending it as an early treatment option to prevent vision loss in patients with clinically significant macular edema.

questions.text:
Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?(INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Goldmann
  2. Richardson
  3. Zeis
  4. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

Richardson and Koeppe are direct gonioscopes.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPY - It is performed with a steep convex lens which permits light from the angle to exit the eye closer to the perpendicular at the lens - air interface. These lenses are used with an operating microscope.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Koeppe goniolens
  • Richardson- Shaffer's lens
  • Sieback goniolens
  • Worth goniolens
  • Swan Jacob's lens
  • Huskins barkan's lens

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPY - uses mirrors or prism to overcome the problem of total internal reflection. Moreover, it uses the slit lamp's illumination and magnification system to its advantage.

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Goldmann Gonioprism
  • Zeis Gonioprism
  • Tokel Gonioprism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct gonioscopes like Richardson and Koeppe provide a detailed and direct view of the anterior chamber angle, which is valuable in diagnostic and certain therapeutic procedures.

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.text: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corneal tattooing

 

Stenopaeic slit is not used in corneal tattooing.

 

Corneal tattooing was introduced as an attempt to mask the leukomatous opacities of the eye during ancient times. Corneal tattooing is also found to reduce glare within the eye due to iris loss and increase visual acuity.

 

Many different types of inks are used throughout history and today for the dyeing of the cornea. Today, India ink is the most commonly used, providing safe and long-lasting effects, but other dyes include metallic colors in powder form, various organic dyes, and uveal pigment from animal eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fincham's test: Used specifically to evaluate differences in the nature of halos seen by patients, aiding in the differential diagnosis between cataract and glaucoma.

 

Option C. Optical Iridectomy: The stenopaeic slit assists in locating the best area on the cornea for performing an iridectomy, essential in cases where peripheral vision needs to be preserved.

 

Option D. To find out the axis in astigmatism: It is instrumental in determining the precise axis for corrective lenses, which is vital for proper astigmatism management.

 

STENOPAEIC SLIT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of stenopaeic slit test:

 

  • Fincham's test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma.
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities.
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism.

questions.text: Defect at the level of the optic chiasma will result in which of the following visual field defects? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

Lesion at the level of the optic chiasma causes bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Hence, the lesion at this level produces bitemporal hemianopia.

 

 

Common causes of the central chiasmal lesion are as follows:

 

  • Suprasellar aneurysms
  • Tumors of the pituitary gland
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Suprasellar meningioma
  • Glioma of the third ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Scotoma - This refers to a loss of vision in the central visual field and is typically associated with diseases affecting the macula or the optic nerve, not lesions at the chiasm.

 

Option B. Bilateral Hemianopia - This would involve a loss of vision in the same half of the visual field of each eye (either left or right), which generally occurs with lesions affecting the optic tract or occipital lobe, not the chiasm.

 

Option C. Binasal Hemianopia - This visual field defect involves loss of vision in the nasal halves (the sides closest to the nose) of both eyes, which is uncommon and would more likely result from unusual patterns of optic nerve damage rather than a central chiasmal lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopia is a classic sign of a lesion at the optic chiasm, often caused by conditions like pituitary tumors or chiasmal compression. This key symptom helps in diagnosing issues that may require urgent intervention to prevent further neurological damage.

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital glaucoma

 

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea, along with the image suggests a diagnosis of congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.

 

 

  • Diagnostic features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.
  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy
  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
      • Goniotomy: to remove obstructed tissue in the eye's drainage system.
      • Trabeculotomy: creates a drainage opening in the eye's trabecular meshwork.
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.
      • Trabeculectomy: creates a new drainage channel for aqueous humor.
      • Tube shunt implantation: involves placing a small tube in the eye to drain excess fluid.
      • Ciliary body ablative procedures: destroy the ciliary body to reduce the production of aqueous humor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinoblastoma: A cancer that would show more than simple enlargement of the corneas, typically presenting with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria).

 

Option C. Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy: Primarily affects the endothelium of the cornea, not associated with the enlargement of the corneas or elevated IOP.

 

Option D. Megalocornea: A non-glaucomatous condition where the corneas are enlarged but without other symptoms like photophobia or increased IOP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital glaucoma is characterized by symptoms like enlarged corneas, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation due to elevated intraocular pressure from developmental anomalies in the anterior chamber angle. Early diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition seen in the image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pterygium

 

  • The given image shows Pterygium which is a triangular/wing shaped encroachment of conjunctiva on the cornea.

 

PTERYGIUM:

 

  • A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea.
  • Typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and may represent a response to UV exposure and chronic surface dryness.
  • Familial.
  • Histologically similar to a pinguecula: shows elastotic degenerative changes in vascularized subepithelial stromal collagen.
  • Encroaches onto the cornea, invading the Bowman layer.
  • Clinical features 
    • Mostly asymptomatic.
    • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying effect.
    • Lesions may interfere with vision by obscuring the visual axis or inducing astigmatism.
    • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
    • Extensive lesions (if recurrent) may have subconjunctival fibrosis extending to the fornices causing restricted ocular excursion.
    • Made up of three parts: a ‘cap’ (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head and a body.
    • Linear epithelial iron deposition (Stocker line): seen in the corneal epithelium anterior to the head of the pterygium.
    • Fuchs islets are small discrete whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells often present at the advancing edge.
    • Aggressive growth or an atypical appearance should prompt excision biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: Unlike pterygium, a pinguecula does not grow across the cornea but remains confined to the conjunctiva. It appears as a yellowish, slightly raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the cornea, usually on the nasal side.

 

Option C. Chemical Burn: This would typically present with more diffuse redness, possible corneal haze, and severe discomfort. The eye would look more acutely inflamed and could show signs of limbal ischemia or whitening.

 

Option D. Thermal Burn: Similar to chemical burns, a thermal burn would involve more diffuse damage and typically present signs of acute injury, such as eyelid burns, charred lashes, or more extensive tissue damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is identifiable by its characteristic growth from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often due to prolonged UV exposure, appearing as a wing-shaped film on the eye.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a history of chronic arthritis on treatment came with complaints of defective vision in both eyes. On examination, vision in RE = 6/12, LE = 6/18, IOP = 18 mmHg in both eyes, and the anterior segment was normal. The fundus examination and fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) findings are shown in the figure. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine toxicity

 

The patient's history of taking medication for rheumatoid arthritis and fundus with a bull's eye sign, along with the FFA image showing increased fluorescence in the macular area and round-shaped blocked fluorescence in the central fovea, suggest likely chloroquine toxicity. Here are some key points about chloroquine toxicity:

 

  • Prolonged administration of chloroquine may lead to a keratopathy, myopathy, retinopathy, and optic neuropathy.
  • Chloroquine retinopathy is a serous pigmentary degeneration of the retina that may result in vision loss.
  • A mild pigmentary disturbance in the macular area causes visual field defects, particularly a central scotoma, and a characteristic "bull's-eye" retinal lesion that can be seen on fluorescein angiography.
  • Eventually, there is a widespread retinal atrophy with pigment clumping and attenuated retinal vessels.
  • Short-term use of chloroquine can produce blurring of vision and diplopia, which is reversible upon stopping the drug.
  • Hydroxychloroquine has a lower risk of ocular toxicity than chloroquine, but it has a weaker anti-inflammatory effect.
  • The maximum dose allowed for chloroquine is 6 mg/kg in 24 hours, while for hydroxychloroquine, it is 4.5 mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine is more commonly used today at a dose of 300-400 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choroiditis: This condition usually presents with patches of inflammation in the choroid, which are not observed in the provided images.

 

Option C. Steroid-induced glaucoma: This would more typically involve elevated intraocular pressure and optic nerve changes, which were not reported in the patient's examination.

 

Option D. Macular edema: While this might also involve changes in the macular region, it generally does not present with the specific "bull's eye" pattern seen in chloroquine toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediately

 

Immediate dilated fundus examination is recommended for individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, as early detection of diabetic retinopathy is crucial for preventing vision loss. Screening at diagnosis is essential because diabetic retinopathy can be asymptomatic in its early stages, yet still pose a risk of significant damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Before his 50th birthday: While this is within five years of diagnosis, immediate examination is preferred for immediate intervention and management.

 

Option C. After his 50th birthday: Delaying the examination could lead to unnoticed progression of diabetic retinopathy and potentially irreversible damage.

 

Option D. When he complains of decrease in vision: Waiting for symptoms such as decreased vision can result in delayed diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy, at which point some damage may be irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

 

  • Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.
  • Glaukomflecken is used to describe an anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity due to necrosis of lens cortical fibers.
  • The mid-dilated pupil is attributed to sphincter atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virchow triad is used to describe the abnormalities that result in thrombosis. It includes endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability of the blood.

 

Option C. Hutchinson triad is used to describe manifestations of congenital syphilis. It includes interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson teeth, and eighth nerve deafness. Hutchinson teeth are screw-driver or peg shaped small incisors.

 

Option D. Gaucher's triad is not a named triad. Hypertonia, strabismus, and stridor usually point to a diagnosis of type 2 Gaucher's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

questions.text: What is the center for vertical gaze? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal

 

Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal is the center for vertical gaze.

 

There are "centers" that control conjugate eye movements. The supranuclear centers are in the cerebral cortex.

 

  • The frontal cortex has an area that controls quick fixational eye movements to the opposite side.
  • The occipital cortex has an area that controls slow pursuit eye movements to the ipsilateral or same side.
  • Both supranuclear areas send impulses to the brainstem and to the centers that control conjugate eye movements.
  • The centers controlling eye movements in the brainstem are the final common pathway conveying impulses for movement in a particular direction.
  • The center controlling horizontal conjugate movements is the pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF), and it controls conjugate horizontal movement to the ipsilateral side.
  • An area controlling vertical movements lies just above the two-third nerve nuclei and is involved in the early development of pinealoma.
  • The center for convergence (Perlia nucleus) is associated with the third nerve nucleus and lies in the region of the Edinger-Westphal complex and an area coordinating divergence possibly exists.

 

 

  • In contrast to horizontal gaze, which is generated by unilateral aggregates of cerebral and pontine neurons, vertical eye movements, with few exceptions, are under bilateral control of the cerebral cortex and upper brainstem.
  • The groups of nerve cells and fibers that govern upward and downward gaze, as well as torsional saccades, are situated in the pretectal areas of the midbrain and involve three integrated structures-
    1. The riMLF (rostral interstitial nucleus of the MLF).
    2. The INC (interstitial nucleus of Cajal)
    3. The nucleus and fibers of the posterior commissure (PC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation: Primarily responsible for horizontal gaze movements, particularly conjugate gaze to the ipsilateral side.

 

Option B. Raphe Nucleus: Involved in serotonin production and has a role in sleep and mood regulation, not directly involved in vertical gaze.

 

Option D. Nucleus of Perlia: Often associated with convergence but its exact role and existence are somewhat controversial and less defined in literature compared to well-defined structures like the INC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal (INC) is the central control site for vertical gaze movements in the brainstem, playing a critical role in coordinating upward and downward eye movements.

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.
There is no pain on ocular movement.
Multiple myeloma is a common cause.
Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about optic neuritis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.

 

In optic neuritis, a characteristic sign is the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil. This can be elicited by performing a swinging flashlight test, where a flashlight is moved between the normal and affected eye while observing the pupil response. Normally, both pupils remain constricted when light is shone on them. However, in the presence of RAPD, the pupil in the affected eye will dilate instead of constrict when the light is moved from the normal eye to the affected eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is known as Marcus Gunn pupil, and is an important diagnostic finding in optic neuritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is no pain on ocular movement:

 

Pain With Eye Movement

 

  • Pain sensation worsening after movement of the eye ball is specific to typical ON. At the site of the apex, the optic nerve sheath is proximal to the superior and medial rectus. Consequently, when the patient moves the eye ball, contraction of the ocular muscles irritates the inflamed optic nerve sheath to cause the pain . It is less likely for patients with anterior ON to develop pain with eye movement, because the optic nerve sheath of the anterior nerve is not pulled by the ocular muscles.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma is a common cause:

 

  • Isolated ON and MS-associated ON (MS-ON) are usually grouped together as typical ON, since they share concurrent characteristics, including age ranging from 18 to 50, unilaterality, pain with eye movement, rapid vision loss, and the tendency to reach the lowest level of visual acuity within two weeks of onset.

 

(Yang X, Li X, Lai M, Wang J, Tan S, Chan HH. Pain Symptoms in Optic Neuritis. Front Pain Res (Lausanne). 2022 Apr 14;3:865032. doi: 10.3389/fpain.2022.865032. PMID: 35498555; PMCID: PMC9046587)

 

  • Atypical ON, especially the neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) associated ON (NMOSD-ON), is more commonly bilateral (around 20%) than MS-ON
  • For differentiated diagnosis, an oligoclonal band (OCB) is more frequently discovered in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of MS patients (85%) than NMOSD patients (15-30%) . The presence of aquaporin protein 4 antibodies (AQP4-IgG), which are found in more than 90% of NMOSD-ON patients in conjunction with the clinical features, helps to diagnose NMOSD with high sensitivity (99%) and specificity (90%).
  • Due to its unique clinical characteristics, including dominance of male gender, a single attack, better recovery of visual acuity, presentation as ON at onset is usually in adults, but presentation as acute demyelinating encephalomyelitis (ADEM) at onset is mostly in children. MOG associated disorder (MOGAD) is increasingly considered as a disease entity distinct from NMOSD.
  • Clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) refers to that the patient underwent a single or multiple phases of neurologic symptoms that might progressed to MS but at that moment these symptoms cannot fulfill the diagnostic criteria of MS (Karussis, 2014).
  • Multiple myeloma is not a known cause of optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Oral corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment:

 

  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is not recommended for optic neuritis.
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone may be used if radiological evidence of multiple sclerosis is present.
  • Oral corticosteroid therapy alone is associated with an increased risk of new attacks of optic neuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A relative afferent pupillary defect is a critical clinical sign in diagnosing optic neuritis, highlighting the asymmetric impact on optic nerve function. Understanding and correctly identifying this sign is vital for early and accurate diagnosis and management of optic neuritis.
